content: The Trade Agreement Enforcement Commission is established to oversee the enforcement of worker rights provisions in trade agreements and preference programs. The Trade Agreement Enforcement Commission, referred to as the Commission, is established with 15 members appointed from private life with expertise in worker rights matters. Members are appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the minority leader, in consultation with relevant committees. The Trade Agreement Enforcement Commission has 15 members appointed from private life with expertise in worker rights matters. Members are appointed by various authorities including the majority leader, minority leader, and the President, with staggered terms for initial appointments. Each member is entitled to one vote, equal to every other member's vote. SEC. 3. DUTIES. The Commission is mandated to monitor and report on the enforcement of worker rights by US trading partners. It includes reviewing enforcement activities and making recommendations for trading partners violating worker rights. The Commission is tasked with monitoring and reporting on worker rights enforcement by US trading partners. Recommendations to the President may include invoking dispute settlement procedures, withdrawing trade preferences, or establishing an ombudsman in territories with worker rights violations. The Commission is responsible for monitoring and investigating worker rights violations in US trading partner countries. They must submit an annual report to Congress and the President, including recommendations for action. The President is also required to report on this issue. The President must report to Congress on actions taken by the executive branch regarding issues addressed in the Commission's report, including implementation of recommendations for worker rights enforcement. SEC. 4. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, request information from federal departments, use the postal services, and manage personnel matters. The Commission members are compensated at a rate equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule, allowed travel expenses, and have staff under the Chairperson. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The compensation for the executive director and staff can be determined by the Chairperson without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. Rates of pay for personnel must not exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can authorize foreign travel for official purposes. Members covered by certain pay authorities are exempt from specific provisions. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may request administrative support services. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission's activities. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "worker rights" refer to provisions in trade agreements or trade preference programs related to worker rights in a trading partner's territory. "Trade preference program" is a program under US laws providing trade preferences to eligible countries. The term "trading partner of the United States" includes countries with trade agreements for tariff reduction and beneficiary countries under trade preference programs. Authorization of appropriations for the Commission to carry out the Act starting in fiscal year 2009 and each year after. The Act will be effective on the first day of the 111th Congress.
